{{redirect-multi|2|Artificial|Man-made}} '''Artificiality''' (also called '''factitiousness''', or the state of being '''artificial''' or '''man-made''') is the state of being the product of intentional human manufacture, rather than occurring [[nature|naturally]] through processes not involving or requiring human activity.
==Connotations== Artificiality often carries with it the implication of being false, counterfeit, or deceptive. The philosopher [[Aristotle]] wrote in his ''[[Rhetoric (Aristotle)|Rhetoric]]'':
{{quote|Naturalness is persuasive, artificiality is the contrary; for our hearers are prejudiced and think we have some design against them, as if we were mixing their wines for them. It is like the difference between the quality of Theodorus' voice and the voices of all other actors: his really seems to be that of the character who is speaking, theirs do not.<ref>[[Aristotle]], ''[[Rhetoric (Aristotle)|Rhetoric]]'', (2004, Dover Publications, W.D. Ross, translator), p. 121.</ref>}}
However, artificiality does not necessarily have a negative connotation, as it may also reflect the ability of humans to replicate forms or functions arising in nature, as with an [[artificial heart]] or [[artificial intelligence]]. Political scientist and artificial intelligence expert [[Herbert A. Simon]] observes that "some artificial things are imitations of things in nature, and the imitation may use either the same basic materials as those in the natural object or quite different materials.<ref name="Simon">[[Herbert A. Simon]], ''The Sciences of the Artificial'' (1996), p. 4.</ref> Simon distinguishes between the artificial and the synthetic, the former being an imitation of something found in nature (for example, an [[artificial sweetener]] which generates [[sweetness]] using a formula not found in nature), and the latter being a replication of something found in nature (for example, a [[sugar]] created in a laboratory that is chemically indistinguishable from a naturally occurring sugar).<ref name="Simon"/> Some philosophers have gone further and asserted that, in a [[Determinism|deterministic]] world, "everything is natural and nothing is artificial", because everything in the world (including everything made by humans) is a product of the physical laws of the world.<ref>Qinglai Sheng, ''Philosophical Papers'' (1993), p. 342.</ref>
==Distinguishing natural objects from artificial objects== [[File:Homebrew reaction diffusion example 512iter.jpg|thumb|right|Pattern resembling a [[Reaction-diffusion]] model, produced using sharpen and blur.]] It is generally possible for humans, and in some instances, for computers,<ref>''See generally, E.P. Baltsavias, A. Gruen, L. VanGool, ''Automatic Extraction of Man-made Objects from Aerial and Space Images'', Volume 3 (2001).</ref> to distinguish natural from artificial environments. The artificial environment tends to have more physical regularity both spatially and over time, with natural environments tending to have both irregular structures and structures that change over time.<ref name="Kaken">Herman Kaken, "Recognition of Natural and Artificial Environments by Computers: Commonalities and Differences", in Juval Portugali, ''Complex Artificial Environments'' (2006), p. 31-48.</ref> However, on close observation it is possible to discern some mathematical structures and [[Patterns in nature|patterns in natural environments]], which can then be replicated to create an artificial environment with a more natural appearance.<ref name="Kaken"/>
For example, by identifying and imitating natural means of [[pattern formation]], some types of [[Finite state machine|automata]] have been used to generate organic-looking [[Texture (computer graphics)|textures]] for more realistic [[Shader|shading]] of [[3D modeling|3D objects]].<ref>Greg Turk, [http://www.cc.gatech.edu/~turk/reaction_diffusion/reaction_diffusion.html Reaction-Diffusion]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Reaction-Diffusion Textures|author=Andrew Witkin, Michael Kassy|url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~aw/pdf/texture.pdf|doi=10.1145/122718.122750|journal=Proceedings of the 18th annual conference on Computer graphics and interactive techniques|year=1991|pages=299–308}}</ref>

'''Aversion to happiness''', also called '''cherophobia''' or '''fear of happiness''', is an attitude towards [[happiness]] in which individuals may deliberately avoid experiences that invoke positive emotions or happiness.<ref>{{cite journal|last2= Lepshokova|first2= Z. K.|last3= Panyusheva|first3= T.|last4= Natalia|first4= A.|last5= Poon|first5= W.-C.|last6= Yeung|first6= V. W.-l.|last7= Sundaram|first7= S.|last8= Achoui|first8= M.|last9= Asano|first9= R.|date= 3 October 2013|title= Cross-Cultural Validation of Fear of Happiness Scale Across 14 National Groups|journal= Journal of Cross-Cultural Psychology|volume= 45|issue= 2|pages= 246–264|doi= 10.1177/0022022113505357|last1= Joshanloo|first1= M.|last10= Igarashi|first10= T.|last11=Tsukamoto|first11= S.|last12= Rizwan|first12= M.|last13= Khilji|first13= I. A.|last14= Ferreira|first14= M. C.|last15= Pang|first15= J. S.|last16= Ho|first16= L. S.|last17= Han|first17= G.|last18= Bae|first18= J.|last19= Jiang|first19= D.-Y.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Joshanloo|first1= Mohsen|last2= Weijers|first2= Dan|title= Aversion to Happiness Across Cultures: A Review of Where and Why People are Averse to Happiness|journal= Journal of Happiness Studies|date= 15 December 2013|volume= 15|issue= 3|pages= 717–735|doi= 10.1007/s10902-013-9489-9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=B4wtDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA342&dq=cherophobia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjY9IiuzbrSAhUp94MKHew2BfEQ6AEIMzAE#v=onepage&q=cherophobia&f=false|title= Mosby's Medical Dictionary|last= Mosby|date= 2016-04-29|publisher= Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn= 9780323414265|language= en}}</ref>
One of several reasons why cherophobia may develop is the belief that when one becomes [[Happiness|happy]], a negative event will soon occur that will taint that happiness, as if punishing that individual for satisfaction. This belief is thought to be more prevalent in [[eastern_world|Eastern]] cultures. In [[Western cultures]], such as [[American culture]], "it is almost taken for granted that happiness is one of the most important values guiding people's [[personal life | lives]]". Western cultures are more driven by an urge to maximize happiness and to minimize sadness. Failing to appear happy often gives cause for concern. The value placed on happiness echoes through Western [[positive psychology]] and through research on subjective well-being.<ref>{{citation |url= https://www.springer.com/about+springer/media/springer+select?SGWID=0-11001-6-1457741-0 |title= What's so bad about feeling happy? |date= 17 March 2014 |author= Joan Robinson |publisher= Springer}}</ref>. Fear of happiness is associated with fragility of happiness beliefs, suggesting that one of the causes of aversion to happiness may be the belief that happiness is unstable and fragile.<ref>{{cite journal|url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10902-014-9553-0|title= Fragility of Happiness Beliefs Across 15 National Groups|first1= Mohsen|last1= Joshanloo|first2= Dan|last2= Weijers|first3= Ding-Yu|last3= Jiang|first4= Gyuseog|last4= Han|first5= Jaechang|last5= Bae|first6= Joyce S.|last6= Pang|first7= Lok Sang|last7= Ho|first8= Maria Cristina|last8= Ferreira|first9= Melikşah|last9= Demir|first10= Muhammad|last10= Rizwan|first11= Imran Ahmed|last11= Khilji|first12= Mustapha|last12= Achoui|first13= Ryosuke|last13= Asano|first14= Tasuku|last14= Igarashi|first15= Saori|last15= Tsukamoto|first16= Sanne M. A.|last16= Lamers|first17= Yücel|last17= Turan|first18= Suresh|last18= Sundaram|first19= Victoria Wai Lan|last19= Yeung|first20= Wai-Ching|last20= Poon|first21= Zarina Kh|last21= Lepshokova|first22= Tatiana|last22= Panyusheva|first23= Amerkhanova|last23= Natalia|date= 1 October 2015|publisher= |journal= Journal of Happiness Studies|volume= 16|issue= 5|pages= 1185–1210|accessdate= 9 February 2018|via= link.springer.com|doi= 10.1007/s10902-014-9553-0}}</ref> Research shows that fear of happiness is associated with avoidant and anxious [[attachment styles]].<ref> {{cite journal |url= https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2017.11.016 |title= Fear and fragility of happiness as mediators of the relationship between insecure attachment and subjective well-being |first= Mohsen|last= Joshanloo |publisher= |journal= Personality and Individual Differences |volume= 123|pages= 115–118 |accessdate= 9 February 2018 |doi= 10.1016/j.paid.2017.11.016 }} </ref>
==Cultural factors== There are four major reasons why cherophobes avoid happiness: "believing that being happy will provoke bad things to happen; that happiness will make you a worse person; that expressing happiness is bad for you and others; and that pursuing happiness is bad for you and others".<ref>{{citation |title=It's time for Western psychology to recognise that many individuals, and even entire cultures, fear happiness |url=http://digest.bps.org.uk/2014/07/its-time-for-western-psychology-to.html |publisher=[[The British Psychological Society]] |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=October 4, 2014}}.</ref> For example, "some people—in Western and Eastern cultures—are wary of happiness because they believe that bad things, such as unhappiness, suffering, and death, tend to happen to happy people."<ref name="livescience44233">{{citation |title=Why Happiness Scares Us |author=Stephanie Pappas |url=http://www.livescience.com/44233-fear-of-happiness.html |publisher=[[LiveScience]] |date=20 March 2014 |accessdate=4 October 2014}}.</ref>
These findings "call into question the notion that happiness is the ultimate goal, a belief echoed in any number of articles and [[self-help]] publications about whether certain choices are likely to make you happy".<ref name="livescience44233"/> Also, "in cultures that believe worldly happiness to be associated with sin, shallowness, and moral decline will actually feel less satisfied when their lives are (by other standards) going well",<ref>{{citation |title=13 of Psychology’s Newest and Coolest Ideas |author=Susan Krauss Whitbourne |url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/fulfillment-any-age/201304/13-psychology-s-newest-and-coolest-ideas |publisher=[[Psychology Today]] |date=6 April 2013 |accessdate=4 October 2014}}.</ref> so measures of personal happiness cannot simply be considered a yardstick for satisfaction with one's life, and attitudes such as aversion to happiness have important implications for measuring happiness across cultures and ranking nations on [[Happiness economics|happiness scores]].

{{Anthropology of religion|Basic|image=[[File:Gudi.jpg|center|x300px]]|caption=A [[Gudi Padwa|Gudhi pole]] in [[Maharashtra]], [[India]]}} A '''ceremonial pole''' symbolizes a variety of concepts in several different cultures. For example, in the [[Miao people|Miao]] culture in [[Yunnan]] [[China]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.people.cn/100668/102822/102827/102830/7455871.html |title=Huashan Festival of the Miao Minority|accessdate=23 October 2015|date=July 30, 2011|publisher=People's Daily Online}}</ref> In ''The Evolution of the Idea of God'', Grant Allen notes that [[Nenets people|Samoyeds]] of Siberia, and [[Damara people|Damara]] of South Africa plant stakes at the graves of ancestors.<ref name="Allen1996">{{cite book|last=Allen|first=Grant |title=The Evolution of the Idea of God|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Phor3HbvIcC&pg=PA42|year=1996|publisher=Health Research Books|location=Pomeroy, WA|isbn=978-0-7873-0022-7|page=42}}</ref> According to Zelia Nuttall in ''The Fundamental Principles Of Old and New World Civilizations'', tree and pole reverence to [[Anu]] in ancient Babylonia-Assyria may have evolved from the fire-drill and beam of the oil press, stating that it was extremely probable that the primitive employment of a fire-stick by the priesthood, for the production of "celestial fire," may have played an important role in causing the stick, and thence the pole and tree, to become the symbol of [[Anu]].<ref name="Zelia Nuttall">{{cite book|last1=Nuttall|first1=Zelia|title=The Fundamental Principles of Old and New World Civilizations|date=March 1901|publisher=Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=362, 504|edition=E-Book|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/32066/32066-h/32066-h.html|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref>
==Asia== ===Myanmar=== ''Kay Htoe Boe'' is a Karenni ancient dance and prayer festival, held by the men in the [[Kayan people (Myanmar)|Kayan community]] in [[Myanmar]] ([[Burma]]). In the Kayan [[Creation myth|creation story]], the Eugenia tree is the first tree in the world. Kay Htoe Boe poles are usually made from the Eugenia tree.<ref name="Khon Pay Yu">{{cite web|last1=Yu|first1=Khon Pay|title=Karenni Festival|url=http://www.huaypukeng.com/KTBfestival.htm|website=www.huaypukeng.com/KTBfestival.htm|publisher=Huay Pu Keng/ huaypukeng.com|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
''Kay Htoe Boe'' poles have four levels, named for the stars, sun and moon, and the fourth level is a ladder made with a long white cotton cloth.<ref name="Khon Pay Yu" />
===Korea=== {{main|Jangseung}} {{main|Sotdae}} [[Image:TsagaanBurgasniiDavaaOvoo.jpg|thumb|right|A predominantly wooden [[ovoo]] in northern [[Mongolia]]]] A ''jangseung'' or ''village guardian'' is a [[Korea]]n ceremonial pole, usually made of wood. Jangseungs were traditionally placed at the edges of villages to mark for village boundaries and frighten away [[demon]]s. They were also worshipped as village [[tutelary deity|tutelary deities]].<ref name="Education in Korea">{{cite book|title=Education in Korea |date=2002|publisher=Ministry of Education and Human Resource Development, Republic of Korea|page= 133|accessdate=26 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=Ah-young>{{cite news|last1=Ah-young|first1=Chung|title=Sculptor keeps traditional Korean woodworking alive|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/common/printpreview.asp?categoryCode=641&newsIdx=173405|accessdate=26 September 2015|publisher=koreatimes.co.kr}}</ref><ref name="Chongsuh Kim">{{cite book|editor-last1=Jackson|editor-first1=Robert|editor-last2=Fujiwara|editor-first2=Satoko|first=Kim |last=Chongsuh|chapter=Contemporary religious conflicts and religious education in the Republic of Korea|title=Peace Education and Religious Plurality: International Perspectives|isbn=9781317969389|date=2013}}</ref>
===Middle East=== {{Main|Asherah pole}} An Asherah pole is a sacred [[tree]] or pole that stood near [[Canaanite religion|Canaanite]] religious locations to honor the [[Asherah|Ugaritic mother-goddess Asherah]], [[Spouse|consort]] of [[El (deity)|El]].<ref>Sarah Iles Johnston, ed. ''Religions of the Ancient World'', (Belnap Press, Harvard) 2004, p. 418; the book-length scholarly treatment is W.L. Reed, ''The Asherah in the Old Testament'' (Fort Worth: Texas Christian University Press) 1949; the connection of the pillar figurines with Asherah was made by [[Raphael Patai]] in ''[[The Hebrew Goddess]]'' (1967)</ref> The relation of the literary references to an ''asherah'' and archaeological finds of Judaean pillar-figurines has engendered a literature of debate.<ref>Summarized and sharply criticized in Raz Kletter's ''The Judean Pillar-Figurines and the Archaeology of Asherah'' (Oxford: Tempus Reparatum), 1996; Kletter gives a catalogue of material remains but his conclusions were not well received in the scholarly press{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}</ref>
The ''asherim'' were also [[cult object]]s related to the worship of the [[fertility god]]dess Asherah, the consort of either Ba'al or, as inscriptions from [[Kuntillet Ajrud|Kuntillet ‘Ajrud]] and Khirbet el-Qom attest, [[Yahweh (Canaanite deity)|Yahweh]],<ref>W.G. Dever, "Asherah, Consort of Yahweh? New Evidence from Kuntillet ʿAjrûd" ''Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research'',1984; D.N. Freedman, "Yahweh of Samaria and his Asherah", ''The Biblical Archaeologist'', 1987; [[Morton Smith]], "God Male and Female in the Old Testament: Yahweh and his Asherah" ''Theological Studies'', 1987; J.M. Hadley "The Khirbet el-Qom Inscription", ''Vetus Testamentum'', 1987</ref> and thus objects of contention among competing cults. The insertion of "''pole''" [[begs the question]] by setting up unwarranted expectations for such a wooden object: "we are never told exactly what it was", observes John Day.<ref>John Day, "Asherah in the Hebrew Bible and Northwest Semitic Literature" ''Journal of Biblical Literature'' '''105'''.3 (September 1986:385-408) p 401; ''asherim'' are discussed pp 401-04.</ref> Though there was certainly a movement against goddess-worship at the Jerusalem Temple in the time of King Josiah, it did not long survive his reign, as the following four kings "did what was evil in the eyes of Yahweh" (2 Kings 23:32, 37; 24:9, 19). Further exhortations came from [[Jeremiah]]. The traditional interpretation of the Biblical text is that the Israelites imported pagan elements such as the Asherah poles from the surrounding Canaanites. In light of archeological finds, however, modern scholars now theorize that the Israelite [[folk religion]] was Canaanite in its inception and always polytheistic, and it was the prophets and priests who denounced the Asherah poles who were the innovators;<ref>William G. Dever, ''Did God have a wife?: Archaeology and folk religion in ancient Israel'', 2005, esp. pp</ref> such theories inspire ongoing debate.<ref>Shmuel Ahituv (2006), ''Did God have a wife?'', ''Biblical Archaeology Review'', Book Review</ref>
===South Asia=== In present times in Indian subcontinent several festivals and celebrations, as in Hinglajmata Sindh, [[Gudi Padwa]], KathiKawadi,<ref name="Sudhir Deore">{{cite book|last1=Deore|first1= Sudhir Rajaram|title=अहिराणी लोकपरंपरा |language= Marathi|trans-title=Ahirani Lok Parampara|date=30 May 2013|publisher=Granthali |location=Mumbai, India|isbn=9789382161967|chapter= काठीकवाडी |trans-chapter= Kathi Kawadi|pages=142|url=https://openlibrary.org/works/OL16500315W/Ahirani_Lok_Parampara|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref> Jatarakathi, Nandidhwaja,<ref name="Bhatt & Bhargava 13">{{cite book|last1=Bhatt|first1=S. C.|last2=Bhargava|first2=Gopal K|title=Land and People of Indian States and Union Territories: Volume No 13|date=2006|publisher=Kalpaz Publications|location=Delhi|isbn=81-7835-369-5|page=488|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=Zo5lvtslcEUC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 October 2015}}</ref> Khambadev<ref name="Sudhir Deore" /> ([[Maharashtra]]), Nimad ([[Madhya Pradesh]]), [[Gogaji]] temple ([[Rajasthan]]) and Khambeshvari ([[Odisha]])<ref name="Bidyut Lata Ray">{{cite journal|last1=Ray|first1= Bidyut Lata|title=The Concept of the Goddess Khambhesvari in The Culture of the Orissan Tribes|journal=Orissa Review|issue=September–October 2005|pages=3|url=http://odisha.gov.in/e-magazine/Orissareview/sept-oct-2005/engpdf/The%20Concept%20of%20the%20Goddess%20Khambhesvari.pdf|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> then in [[Tripura]] and in [[Manipur]], central poles are features in temple and festival settings.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
According to [[Adi Parva]] ([[Textual criticism|critical edition]]) of Indian epic [[Mahabharata]] a [[Bamboo|Bamboo festival]] named ''Shakrotsava'' was Celebrated in [[Chedi Kingdom]].<ref>[[Adi Parva]] ([[Textual criticism|critical edition]]) of Indian epic [[Mahabharata]] 1.63</ref> Uparichara Vasu was a king of Chedi belonging to the [[Puru (Vedic tribe)|Puru]] dynasty. He was known as the friend of [[Indra]]. During his reign, Chedi kingdom introduced ''Shakrotsava'' festival in his kingdom in the honor of Indra. The festival involved planting of a bamboo pole every year, in honor of Indra. The king will then pray for the expansion of his cities and kingdom. After erecting the pole, people decked it with golden cloth and scents and garlands and various ornaments. (1,63).
==Europe== {{Main|Maypole|Mære Church}} [[File:Maypole Sweden.jpg|thumb|300px|Dancing around the maypole, in [[Åmmeberg]], Sweden]] A [[maypole]] is a tall wooden pole erected as a part of various European folk festivals, around which a maypole dance often takes place.
The festivals may occur on [[May Day]] or [[Pentecost]] ([[Whitsun]]), although in some countries it is instead erected at [[Midsummer]]. In some cases the maypole is a permanent feature that is only utilised during the festival, although in other cases it is erected specifically for the purpose before being taken down again.
Primarily found within the nations of [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] Europe and the neighbouring areas which they have influenced, its origins remain unknown, although it has been speculated that it originally had some importance in the [[Germanic paganism]]<ref name="Russel Jefferry Burton">{{cite book|last1=Russel|first1=Jefferry Burton|title=Medieval Civilisation|orig-year=1968 |date=22 February 2005 |publisher=Wipf and Stock Publishers |location=Eugene|isbn=1-59752-103-5|page=243|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=C05LAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA243}}</ref> of [[Iron Age]] and early Medieval cultures, and that the tradition survived Christianisation, albeit losing any original meaning that it had. It has been a recorded practice in many parts of Europe throughout the [[Medieval]] and [[Early Modern]] periods, although became less popular in the 18th and 19th centuries. Today, the tradition is still observed in some parts of Europe and among European communities in North America.<ref name="Kelly Cannon">{{cite news|last1=Cannon|first1=Kelly|title=Good Neighbor: Former teacher continues tradition of Maypole dance|url=http://news.hjnews.com/news/good-neighbor-former-teacher-continues-tradition-of-maypole-dance/article_43e9b2fb-2f30-54b6-aeb3-34398c645005.html|accessdate=28 September 2015|work=From the Good Neighbors series|agency=The Herald Journal's Staff writer|issue=May 21, 2015|publisher=The Herald Journal, 75 West 300 North Logan, UT|date=May 21, 2015}}</ref>
The fact that they were found primarily in areas of Germanic Europe, where, prior to Christianisation, [[Germanic paganism]] was followed in various forms, has led to speculation that the maypoles were in some way a continuation of a Germanic pagan tradition.<ref name="Russel Jefferry Burton" /> One theory holds that they were a remnant of the Germanic reverence for sacred trees, as there is evidence for various sacred trees and wooden pillars that were venerated by the pagans across much of Germanic Europe, including [[Thor's Oak]] and the [[Irminsul]].<ref>''A History of Pagan Europe'' by Prudence Jones and Nigel Pennick, Routledge, 1997, {{ISBN|0-415-15804-4}}, {{ISBN|978-0-415-15804-6}}, p. 119.</ref><ref name="James Frazer">{{cite book|last1=Frazer|first1=James George|title=The Golden Bough: A Study in Magic and Religion|date=1922|page=Chapter 10:: Relics of Tree Worship in Modern Europe|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Golden_Bough|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> It is also known that, in [[Norse paganism]], [[cosmology|cosmological]] views held that the universe was a [[world tree]], known as [[Yggdrasil]].<ref>'The London quarterly review, Volumes 113-114', Theodore Foster, 1863, p. 117.</ref><ref>'The History of Religions' By Hopkins Edward Washburn, The McMillan Company 1929, p. 166.</ref><ref>''European paganism: the realities of cult from antiquity to the Middle Ages'' by [[Ken Dowden]], Routledge, 2000, {{ISBN|0-415-12034-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-415-12034-0}}, p. 119.</ref><ref>'Nart sagas from the Caucasus: myths and legends from the Circassians, Abazas, Abkhaz, and Ubykhs' by [[John Colarusso]], Princeton University Press, 2002, {{ISBN|0-691-02647-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-691-02647-3}}, p. 102.</ref><ref>'The early history and antiquities of Freemasonry: as connected with ancient Norse guilds, and the oriental and mediæval building fraternities' by George Franklin Fort, Bradley, 1881, p. 361.</ref>
The floor of the [[Mære Church]], [[Norway]], was excavated in 1969<ref>Lidén, Hans-Emil. 1969. From Pagan Sanctuary to Christian Church, the Excavation of Mære Church in Trøndelag. Norwegian Archaeological Review. (1969) 2, pp. 3–32.</ref> and found to contain the remains of a pagan cult structure. The nature of that structure was not clear. Lidén felt this represented the remains of a building, but a critique by Olsen (1969:26) in the same work suggested this may have been a site for pole-related rituals. A recent review of the evidence by Walaker (Norddide 2011: 107-113)<ref>Walaker Nordeide, Sæbjorg. 2011. The Viking Age As a Period of Religious Transformation: The Christianization of Norway from AD 560 to 1150/1200. {{ISBN|2503534805}}, Brepols Publishers.</ref> concluded that this site was similar to the site in Hove (Åsen, also in Nord-Trøndelag) and was therefore likely the site of a ceremonial pole.
==Oceania== {{main|Cook Islands art#Staff God}} In [[Māori mythology|Māori]] mythology, [[Rongo]] – the god of cultivated food, especially the [[Sweet potato|kūmara]], a vital food crop – is represented by a god stick called ''whakapakoko atua''.<ref name="Whakapakoko atua">{{cite web|title=Whakapakoko atua (Story: Kaitiakitanga – guardianship and conservation Part of page 5 – Key concepts)|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/11598/whakapakoko-atua|website=www.teara.govt.nz|publisher=Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=2 October 2015|ref=Te Ahukaramū Charles Royal. 'Kaitiakitanga – guardianship and conservation - Key concepts', Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand, updated 8-Jul-13}}</ref>
In the [[Cook Islands]] Cult figures called staff-gods or ''atua rakau'' from [[Rarotonga]], apparently combine images of gods with their human descendants. They range in length between 28 inches (71 cm) and 18 feet (5.5 m) and were carried and displayed horizontally.<ref>[https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=qGb4pyoseH4C&pg=PT751&lpg=PT751&dq=rarotonga+staff+god&source#v=onepage&q=rarotonga%20staff%20god&f=false A world history of art by Hugh Honour & John Fleming (2005)]</ref>
